timeline.body: Is there a reason you need to pass in `subscriptionId`?  It seems like that could be handled internally within `SubscriptionEndpoint`.  It doesn't appear that `subscriptionId` is actually used anywhere else in `SubscriptionOperation`, except for checking if it's null in `cancel()`, which doesn't seem like a necessary check anyway.

timeline.body:
This is a topic I haven't closed in my own mind, yet:

If a cancellable object encounters an error, or terminates gracefully, is it canceled?
 - Yes! Of course, since it can't be useful anymore;
 - No; no-one asked for it to stop (cancellation), it just did.

😖 

---------------------

If you do (1), though, should you also mark `canceld.set(true)` for the `onSubscriptionComplete` path?

timeline.bodyHTML:
This is a topic I haven't closed in my own mind, yet:

If a cancellable object encounters an error, or terminates gracefully, is it canceled?

  • Yes! Of course, since it can't be useful anymore;
  • No; no-one asked for it to stop (cancellation), it just did.

😖

If you do (1), though, should you also mark canceld.set(true) for the onSubscriptionComplete path?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText:
Right...I feel like we're missing a representation of a state here. In my mind, we're missing a representation of the type of cancelation that took place: was it gracefully canceled, or was it a result of some error condition.
I started doing some refactoring here, but ended up going down a rabbit hole so I shelved those changes for now. Probably something that needs to be looked at more broadly.
replies.author: rjuliano

timeline.body:
Could you have `waitForConnectionReady` return like a `Connection` object? It could have a status, and optionally, this failure detail. On L122, you could do like:
```java
Connection connection = webSocketListener.waitForConnection();
if (connection.hasFailure()) {
    ...
```
Then, here,
```java
new ApiException(connection.getFailureDetail(), ...)
```
The point of this would be so that you don't have to cache it inside of the listener.

timeline.body: When does this situation arise? And if the the subscription was _not_ still pending, but we're in this catch block, isn't there still some error case?
timeline.bodyText: When does this situation arise? And if the the subscription was not still pending, but we're in this catch block, isn't there still some error case?
timeline.bodyHTML: When does this situation arise? And if the the subscription was not still pending, but we're in this catch block, isn't there still some error case?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText:
For us to get here, we know that the subscription was added to the pendingSubscriptionIds set and we have a good connection. These two exceptions can happen either because of some malformed value passed into the put calls, or if createHeadersForSubscription throws an ApiException.
If the subscription was not pending, it's likely because cancel() was invoked some time after the connection was successfully established, but before the subscription handshake completed.
replies.author: rjuliano
